Both men and women were jointly providing services, and both were getting sex, but most negotiations were familial anyway. And even later, once married women were hardly the "keepers" of sex - they were subject to the will of their husbands, leading to John Stuart Mill quote on marriage as the invisible tyranny. So anyway, a far cry from this presentation of "good old days" marriage as a negotiation between two people, marriage was a familial economic planning activity involving the subjugation of women.  But women still bought in because it was the only way they could have sex without suffering community censure.

Comment: PR can seem fair on the surface but looking deeper paints a different picture. 

The Ont Citizens' Assembly's 2007 Mixed Member Proportional (MMP) proposal, for example, proposed 70% of the seats to be locally elected using our very imperfect First Past the Post (FPTP). Then to create approximate proportionality the other 30% would come from a party list that voters had little control over.

How utterly ridiculous to use FPTP (the very flawed system we are try to get rid of) to elect the local candidate which is the candidate that is closest and most relevant to the voter. They should have at least proposed the ranked ballot for the local candidates to ensure the majority of voters get the candidate of their choice. A lot of MMP models use FPTP which is totally inexplicable!

And something like STV is cumbersome with a very complex counting system.

So, no, 10 year olds won't always understand PR. But they would understand ranked ballots which would be a simple yet huge improvement.

Comment: ------------
"HFCs are now the world’s fastest growing greenhouse gases, increasing roughly 10 per cent per year. They are also one of the most powerful, trapping a thousand times more heat in the Earth’s atmosphere than carbon dioxide."
---------------

HFCs and CFCs have from 800 to 10,000 times the global warming potential of CO2, but this is on a molar basis. Their much lower concentration in the atmosphere means that they currently account for global warming that is about 1/6 the magnitude of that caused by the extra CO2 added to the atmosphere by human activities. However,  as noted, HFCs were and are increasing rapidly.

Comment: Bronson Kaahui, You might take a look at federal law to figure out the composition of the well regulated militia.
"§246. Militia: composition and classes
(a) The militia of the United States consists of all able-bodied males at least 17 years of age and, except as provided in section 313 of title 32, under 45 years of age who are, or who have made a declaration of intention to become, citizens of the United States and of female citizens of the United States who are members of the National Guard.
(b) The classes of the militia are-
(1) the organized militia, which consists of the National Guard and the Naval Militia; and
(2) the unorganized militia, which consists of the members of the militia who are not members of the National Guard or the Naval Militia."
The well regulated militia is the organized militia, consisting of the National Guard and the Naval Militia.

Comment: This is the crux of the argument and I'm glad we're here.

We both want the same thing, we just have the exact opposite strategy.

I believe that people like Tyler and I (and probably you) stand to benefit from development. Because there just is not enough supply right now, and it's fucking everything up.

SF is, to my eye, the example of your approach while Seattle is my approach. In SF, they won't let anybody build anything but they have rent control—all that does now is lock-in the old Boomers, who hate their new market rate neighbors. Seattle built fast and rents there have actually fallen, finally, after that building boom. The upward pressure was relieved.

How will it play out? Well, I might be right and I might be wrong, but I think development will save Portland culture by stemming the insane lack of supply. And for this perspective I get a lot of flak.

Comment: Hi, there. ADN's DC reporter popping in with some info: 
President Obama, like all presidents before him, has submitted a budget request to Congress each year. This year's budget request had a photo of Denali on the cover: http://bit.ly/1Q78ylA  More on the request: https://www.whitehouse.gov/omb/budget 

Generally, Congress holds the purse strings. But the inability to get through the full appropriations process is not one party's dysfunction. The last time Congress & the White House made it through the entire 12-bill appropriations process was in 1997, with a deal between President Clinton & House Speaker Newt Gingrich: http://wapo.st/2bdE3uE 

Returning to "regular order" and passing all 12 individual appropriations bills is a key priority for the (Republican) Senate this year. They will get closer than they have in a long time, but since it's an election year, it's unlikely they'll make it to the finish line without passing another "omnibus" spending bill.

Comment: As you note, when used as a term denoting sentimental disposition, "racist" is empty of significant moral importance. As a term describing material policies and actions, however, it is morally significant. I maintain that functionally, materially, we are all inescapably racist, without respect to our sentiments. Racism is essentially baked in. It is the historic and ongoing structure of material racial injustice that begs to be addressed, and the most pertinent sentiment, with respect to that project, is a will for justice, and a willingness both to acknowledge unjust privilege, and to put it on the table, so that the benefits of society may be more justly distributed. Our reluctance to do so is profoundly evident, across the political spectrum. It's the one thing on which most of us agree, some tacitly, and some vociferously.

If the children of the rich investor class and the political class were homeless, say during a depression, there would be shelters on every block. The downtown LCC and old city hall  have been pressed into service as a shelter.

I blame the Bill Clinton faction of the Democratic Party most of all. They cheered as NAFTA and other acts of true stupidity encouraged jobs to move to China or Mexico or wherever, and they cheered as he did what he could to get rid of the safety net for those without resources.

Hugh Massengill, Eugene Oregon

Comment: Without a doubt these kind of situations will continue to happen whether they be negligent third-party care for children or adults. If the cause is shoddy State oversight, irresponsible care operators or unreported and disregarded care standards then closer regulation and stricter accountability is indeed in order.
But I'll dare venture into a bigger question that many may be too afraid to broach : Why would any responsible parent turn over their 4 month child to a stranger? Why would any responsible parent trade the critical early nurturing care and safety of their 4 month infant in order to return to work?
I am sympathetic to this couple's tragedy but an inward examination of their share of responsibility is in order.

Comment: Not immediately. I was trying to calculate pyramiding when I came across a tax foundation article about Washington State tax system and they authors stated Hawaii had eliminated pyramiding. But we can go further. We have an actual amount prices are effected, that amount is .0016. The legislature took a calculation which I considered extreme and allowed sellers to collect that amount as part of their transactions. That is not passed on to the state. The pyramiding as described in the article is how GET affects the well off. They pay GET on legal fees, for example, if its a business in effect its a tax on business. Now there is a whole literature on shifting tax burdens, seldom is it a straight pass through. So the "baked in" part, is tiny .0016. And that's based on extreme and dated calculation. Big box stores flatten the logistical steps,  bringing in goods directly. Same with Amazon. Now pyramiding is all those services well off people pay for. All taxes have that, property taxes.

Comment: Important for Alaska pilots, buried in the FAA bill is a "Pilot's Bill of Rights".  This is now signed into law. For many years the Experimental Aircraft Assoc. and the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Assoc. has petitioned the regulators in the FAA Medical offices for reform.  This new law has now fixed this problem.  Thank you Senators Murkowski and Sullivan.  Rep. Comment: I am no fan of Donald Trump and find most of what he says dispicable, and agree with him on very little.  However I think Lawrence mis-characterizes Trump in at least two areas

1/  The wall with Mexico is not to keep out immigrants, but illegal migrants.  This is a very big difference, as immigrants would receive proper legal approval to move to the US prior to arriving.  Illegal migrants simply cross the border and live illegally in the US.  Neglecting this distinction mis-characterizes both Trump and his position, regardless of the merits of either.  

2/ Did Donald Trump call for the death penalty for the accused in the Central Park rape because or race, or did the accused just happen to be of minority race?  We cannot know what Trump would have done so many years ago had the accused not been of minority race, or if he knew the Police wrongly accused those boys at the time .  

But assuming the worst, even for Donald Trump, is not at all helpful to improve race relations.

Comment: Your previous post (sorry if I misread) that you can only have sex when you *intend* pregnancy is not accurate regarding Church teaching.  You don't have to intend it, just allow it. Comment: Do you know who loves a higher minimum wage? Amazon

Amazon's business model is such that they have very few minimum wage jobs as a percent of total workers, so a higher minimum wage does not have a big effect on them.

On the other hand, Amazon's competitors, the local mom and pop shops, are standard retail, and like fast food, retail has one of the highest proportions of minimum wage jobs. A higher minimum wage will therefore increase their costs dramatically.

So congratulations Wynne...you just gave giant corporations like Amazon an even further competitive advantage over the small mom and pop shops.

Comment: There is a difference, at least for me, in treating a person with dignity whether he or she has same sex attraction or not, and allowing a person with same sex attraction to be ordained as a Catholic priest. In Christian theology, Jesus is the Lamb provided by God himself as a sacrifice for the sins of the world. The Catholic priest, in offering the holy sacrifice of the Mass, participates as an essential person in the mystical process whereby Jesus Himself becomes present. The Catholic priest, in the sacrament of Reconciliation, hears the deepest secrets of the penitent, who must have utter confidence in his silence even in torture. The Catholic priest, in all the sacraments, must have the full acceptance and respect of the faithful, and his presence should not be the source of thoughts outside the sacrament itself. A priest who "outs" himself creates an untenable situation, which the church seeks to avoid by ordaining only persons who will not be the source of anger or pain to others

Comment: PeePee. How in the world can you possibly see this as a Liberal vs Conservative issue? Arguably one of the greatest conservationist in American history was Teddy Roosevelt, a Republican President. He was a renowned hunter, but recognized the importance of resource protection and conservation. He saw that natural resources were limited. We can thank forward looking leaders like TR from across the political spectrum for protecting and preserving places like Yellowstone and Yosemite, and for preventing the complete extinction of the American Buffalo. Federal wildlife refuges today preserve great opportunities for fishing and hunting, but also manage wildlife in a science-based manner. By all accounts, the BOG manages first and foremost for human harvest. This might be what some Alaskans want. I and others oppose the notion that we're all guaranteed a moose in our freezer every year at the expense of sound wildlife management.

Comment: I can't respond for me^you, but I can tell you my answer.

Gallup reported several years ago that most Americans don't like their jobs (https://tinyurl.com/kl97b4o).  

I LOVED my job.  It was a joy to go to work every day.  I was paid substantially less than my comparators with similar education in the private sector and worked longer hours but I did not care.  I was living where I wanted, following my passion.

My many supervisors over the years always said, "I wish I could do more with the salary, but you will have a good retirement."  And they were right.  I do.

I  was once offered a job in the private health care sector for more than twice what I was making in my public employment, but I turned it down because I knew I would be miserable in that private setting.  

We all make choices in life.  I think I made a lot of good ones along the way with a few bad calls.  I feel I earned my salary and pension in a job that I loved.

Comment: The Oregon Forest Practices Act allows the worst industrial logging practices on the west coast to take place on private and state land. Without the destructive soil eroding and compacting practice of clearcutting forest that invite invasive species, there would be no need for herbicides.  Go look at a replanted post-harvest doug fir monoculture, it is not a forest, it does not possess the biodiversity of a forest.  Selectively harvesting trees causes little environment impact, creates more jobs, and yields more board feet per acre over time.  We need to end clearcutting altogether.

Comment: FYI. The forecast for economic growth resulting from the planned cuts is not 1%, it is 0.1% with some at 0.2% and that will not reduce or stop the growth of the deficit. There are several reasons why this happens. One is that money spend on stocks increases the price of shares, but may not increase cash or investment by companies waiting to see growth in employment and income. In fact in recent years most of corporate cash has been used to buy back shares to increase stock prices, or hoarded by companies waiting for real growth in consumer spending. Cash from stock buy backs goes to shareholders and that is often just invested in buying more shares, and so on. The small group that makes up the rich, already spend a lot, therefore, even a large tax cut is not enough to generate the kind of spending increase (and resulting investment) that even a small increase for the middle class can have.

Comment: Hofstader's book was published in 1963, it was not written about 1963. It was a historical exploration of how anti-intellectualism was "cool" pretty much right from the beginning of the U.S. He followed it with an essay in 1964 about how the 'paranoid' style was similarly historically ingrained in American culture and politics. He was not writing about 1964, he was explaining how the paranoia rising in American politics in 1964 was not new and had deep historical roots.

Yellow journalism in major news publications (reaching the many). Local dinners. Zines. Water coolers. Jewish conspiracy. Papal conspiracy. Masonic conspiracy. UFOs. Communists in every corner. Misinformation and paranoia could and did spread very wide and very fast.

Those who lack awareness beyond ten years are prone to believe that somehow what happens today is new and different, bigger and worse. Ultimately, trapped in a their own bubble of misinformation, hyperbole and paranoid belief. Ironic, eh?

Comment: Steve, I have no problem whatsoever with people taking what is rightfully theirs.  Working for a fair wage or turning an ethical profit is what makes the economy hum.

That was the mantra when I was at university in the early 80s, and it brought Reaganomics, junk bonds, and irresponsible cuts, which were the gestation of the decline of the middle class and the increasing gap between rich and poor.

I have a comfortable lifestyle by dint of hard work.  But I don’t object to society helping those who aren’t as fortunate as I am; we weren’t all blessed with good health and reasonable intellect.  I don’t grumble too much about the taxes I have to pay, either – while I deplore the waste I see in government, I also see people who would have neither food nor shelter if it weren’t for publicly funded programs.

Comment: Nonsense, Trump didn't scrub White House website, that was done by Obama Administration on the way out the door. In its place, is a temporary website that will be added to over time, as was Obama's.

Can people control climate? Unlikely —  99.9+% of gases in Earth's atmosphere are not there by or under the control of any government. The science on whether CO2, the building block of all life on Earth, warms the Earth is mixed at best. As it has risen the Earth's temperatures have not. It was no warmer in 2016 than in 1998, for example. What affects temperatures the most is, of course, the Sun. El Nino and La Nina, two natural phenomena are unrelated to CO2 and scientists have no firm conclusion on what causes them. So the charade that we can control the Earth's climate needs to be challenged. Do we put energy into the atmosphere? Yes. Is it significant enough to change the climate? So far the evidence doesn't match the claims or modelling.

Comment: It's kind of a weird demand side issue for toys. With the affluence of the middle class, Toys R Us has been able to stock a huge variety of toys for decades.  If, after this period of time, toys are not naturally natural looking, I have to wonder if the demand side will allow for the supply side to be as diverse as you would like.  Natural looking isn't as compelling as vibrant looking, especially at a doll or action figure sized toy.  I think it's an honorable position to want kids to have identifiable choices in toys that honor their skin color and move idealism away from the Barbie standard.  But if you have to ask Mattel to do it, it's not the structure that Mattel finds itself in; Capitalism.  They sell what sells. Comment: Mike, you need to go back another 50 years or more, to the beginning of the decline. 

By the late 50's the Cook Inlet fisheries were in decline. The Susitna use to produce hogs that rivaled the Kenai, before the Parks Hwy was built. It was the Russian River that was the big draw on the Peninsula before the roads from Soldotna into Kenai and down to Homer were improved. It was then Pike were introduced to lakes on both sides of the Inlet. Talk with existing members of the Gabbert family as to the impact on their Alexander Creek Lodge. In the 80's, well meaning Native activist started putting their nets in the mouth of the Kenai which opened the door to today's rape of the Kenai.

Comment: Hawaii has enacted the National Popular Vote bill.  

It would replace state winner-take-all laws that award all of a state’s electoral votes to the candidate who get the most popular votes in each separate state (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states), in the enacting states

The bill retains the constitutionally mandated Electoral College and state control of elections, and uses the built-in method that the Constitution provides for states to make changes. It ensures that every voter is equal, every voter will matter, in every state, in every presidential election, and the candidate with the most votes wins, as in virtually every other election in the country.
	
All of the 270+ presidential electors from the enacting states will be supporters of the presidential candidate receiving the most popular votes in all 50 states (and DC)—thereby guaranteeing that candidate with an Electoral College majority.

NationalPopularVote

Comment: In 2006, when Sarah Palin became governor, the state budget was set at $60 a barrel. That's 30% less than it is today. The price of oil went up and the Legislature submitted a budget that climbed with the price of oil. Palin line-item vetoed much of it and put the excess earnings in savings accounts. That's what we've been paying the deficits with since 2009 when Parnell became governor and allowed the budget to chase the price of oil. Programs exploded in size.

Over the last two years, DOT has been cut by 23%, but most other agencies in the State have received only minimal cuts. Some have actually grown. DOT is still doing its job, though it may be at right-size now.

So, yes, we can cut our way to a balanced budget. Just roll back spending in those other agencies, back to 2008 spending levels. Yeah, it will be painful, but the world won't end. We'll still be paying a good deal more for State government than any other state in the union. $60 a barrel should be the goal.

Comment: As a point of clarification, a portion of the quoted payment is only available to GP doctors, meaning for a specialist MAID procedure pays $200, flat rate.

MAID procedure involves the following components:

1. Go to pharmacy, complete paperwork, collect medications ( by law only the doctor can pick this up, not a proxy)
2. Drive to patient home.
3. Completely reassess patient eligibility.  Confirm consent.
4. Answer all questions from patient and often also friends and family present.
5. Prepare the medications (they are not prepared in advance by pharmacy)
6. Establish IV
7. Administer medications.
8. Monitor until death (up to 15 min)
9. Aftercare of family/friends.
10. Clean up.
11. Drive back to pharmacy, complete medication return protocol ( cannot delegate this)
12. Drive back to office.
13. Complete 27 pages of provincially mandated paperwork and write up procedure summary.
14. Self care and reflection.

This averages 3.5 hours.  And office expenses still run.

Comment: The fluid dynamics cannot be predicted because the math problem has not been solved yet , not because of measurement errors.
You are correct in that time magnifies errors ,that was demonstrated in the NOVA program you mentioned.
How does identifying a pattern , in this context ,make it use full in making weather predictions years into the  future?
Climate models make 100 year predictions , 20 minutes at a time .One grid cell at a time ,from the surface to about 8km high ,if memory serves me correct.
That is lots of time and space to compound errors ,making the uncertainty around the prediction so large as to make the prediction useless.
Dr Judith Curry has a good explanation of it for us layman at 
Climate models for the layman @  http://www.thegwpf.org/content/uploads/2017/02/Curry-2017.pdf

Comment: Precisely correct, just as you get to decide for whom you will work, the baker is the only individual with the right to determine who hires him to bake a unique cake for the sole benefit of the other person at some future date.  It is called a contract; and in order for it to be a valid contract all parties must be voluntary and willing participants. Why an individual chooses not to enter into a contract is irrelevant, for the contract to be valid it must be willingly entered into or else the contract is invalid. Law students learn this in their first contract law class. Doesn't matter if the contract is to provide a custom cake on a specified date, or build a custom home to the specifications of a homeowner, or to mow a property owners lawn every Tuesday prior to sunset.  No one, since the passage of the 13th Amendment, has the right to unilaterally decide someone else must labor for their benefit involuntarily.

Comment: This is a well written article, but it fails to address a couple of key components. First, immigration is great as long as it is done legally. Family separation, detention, and issues where people are scared or taken advantage of is a direct consequence of entering the country illegally. Second, the ban is temporary to allow for a careful examination of the vetting process. Due to threats to the country, we must look carefully at the current vetting procedures and modify as necessary. No one is saying that foreign people who enter the country have no value. It is simply that we must look more carefully at how people enter the country and their true motive for entering the country to ensure the well-being of everyone. A temporary ban will give officials time to develop a more streamlined system to achieve those goals.

Comment: As a kid, I always thought it was awesome to go to the houses with decorated yards. Graveyards, webbing and other spooky stuff. Flashing light simulating science experiments inside, or blacklights. One house close by would take their garage and make a mini haunted house. It wasn't hard hearing sounds of chains, footsteps, creaking doors, screams, sadistic laughs and such while walking around the neighborhood. It seemed like most houses had carved pumpkins and got into the spirit, even if it was only window decorations. About 6 of 10 homes had lights on and candy to give. Topping it off was coming back home to hot chocolate or apple cider with a candy apple.

I don't want to deprive my children of a similar experience. The senses are stimulated, and there's a side benefit to them interacting with neighbors, with us present, in my opinion.

The mazes and patches, really, could be done anytime. The problem, as seen with some streets now, is having 2 out of 10 homes lit. Spirit is lacking.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: This statement is at best ill worded:  'Canadians do not pay capital-gains tax on the sale of their primary residence, the first $800,000 of gains from the sale of a small business, farm or fishing property, and profits inside registered accounts, such as RRSPs and TFSAs.'

Within an RSP, when withdrawn all monies are treated as income and subject to full tax.  Within an RSP you lose all tax benefits including the capital gains tax and the dividend tax credit.  So rather than paying the capital gains tax at a discounted rate when an RSP is redeemed you pay at a significantly higher rate.   The tax treatment of gains within an RSP is totally different than a TFSA .

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: I have to disagree with you.

You can only squeeze in so many patients in one day before the quality of care  suffers.  I've seen it in a doctor's office where patients are treated like they're on a conveyor belt.  In and out fast.  It gave me the impression the doctor was more interested in cranking up the billings.

If I am going to see a doctor to assess a problem, I don't think I would be comfortable with a doctor who rushes through their diagnostic exam just so they can fill up their roster with more patients.  Such a situation will bring  liability issues and malpractice lawsuits if misdiagnosis leads to something more serious.  Will the government take on such liabilities?

There is quite a difference between any other small business and a doctor's office.  In a doctor's office, only a medical professional is able to treat the patient.

I don't begrudge physicians their high incomes.  It's a long road with lots to learn.  Not everyone is inclined to be in the medical profession.

Comment: How can a Canada 10-year bond purchased today possibly lose 2.2% per year over the next seven years?

First that bond yields close to 1.8% currently. For it to lose 2.2% per year, that mean after the interest paid on the bond, the value of the bond would need to decline by approximately 4.0% per year. That means seven years from today, the value that the bond is trading at would need to be some 31% lower than it trades at today and it wuld have only three years to go until it matured at par. It's three year yield to maturity would be somewhere around  16% per year. 

This scenario is very doubtful.

Comment: Commercial fishing is a billion dollar industry. To claim it is defenseless against "industry captains" and their political allies is farcical. 

And while it is a key industry in Alaska, it pales in economic significance to oil and gas, mining, and construction. It also pays a pittance in tax revenue to the state. Most of the revenue generated by the industry flows to Seattle which is attested to by many Washingtonians making the Forbes 500 list due to their lucrative fishing interests.

Let's call a spade a spade. This initiative is being bankrolled and sponsored by outside environmental groups on a crusade against resource development with a few local residents to put a friendly face on it. I challenge the author to point to one example where mining, oil and gas, or construction have eradicated a salmon watershed. Susitna-watana couldn't be more dead.

The truth is that commercial bycatch likely contributes more to salmon run depletion than any other "industrial" activity.

Comment: Let's face it, while living in Anchorage on under $25K/year is precarious, there are some things we know can help. 1) We need a smoother transition in and out of aid programs so that a little bit of financial luck does not result in your life coming crashing down, nor small misfortune bring down what should remain sound. 2) We need to stop having more children than we can afford to raise properly. 3) We need low cost universal healthcare and effective long term disability insurance (premiums are only ~$100.month but rules are labyrinthine ). 4) There is no substitute for direct benefit pensions - everyone should have one. 5) We need to recognize that a substantial portion of our population really can't take care of themselves; they can't cook, care for their home, or even manage their own money. That needs to change.

Comment: Thanks for your kind words. I've appreciated our conversation, on this otherwise quiet thread. 

I don't disagree about there being a violent subculture, doing great harm within many Black neighborhoods.  Cliques of undirected and disenchanted young men and boys are one of the long-standing challenges of modern societies. Where a society understands those youths to be its own children and future, it tends to take seriously the job of engaging them productively. Where societies do not regard them as their own children, it's of little consequence what happens to them. 

Good luck with Anderson's book. She has a contentious thesis, but I think she does good work assembling an historically based overview. At the very least, it may give you a more detailed sense of the sorts of things people have in mind, when they argue the merits of taking an historical view of current conditions in Black communities, as I have tried to do here.

All the best

Modern oil development methods may already be making Alaska prospects uneconomic.  Our fisheries are impacted by factors that we do not yet understand, whether it is ocean acidification, warming, or invasive competitive species.  Our legislature demonstrates an appalling ignorance of our current economy, much less what we should anticipate. They seem to have no appreciation of the future impacts of the budget cuts they seek to education and services.  What is proposed will require Federal money. With only one Representative we need someone who can work in the state's interest across party lines and rise in the power structure and not be blocked from significant positions because he has been there to long and be respected by his or her peers.

From Norms For The Distribution And Reception Of Holy Communion Under Both Kinds In The Dioceses Of The United States Of America:

"54.	The Precious Blood may not be reserved, except for giving Communion to someone who is sick. Only sick people who are unable to receive Communion under the form of bread may receive it under the form of wine alone at the discretion of the Priest. If not consecrated at a Mass in the presence of the sick person, the Blood of the Lord is kept in a properly covered vessel and is placed in the tabernacle after Communion. The Precious Blood should be carried to the sick in a vessel that is closed in such a way as to eliminate all danger of spilling. If some of the Precious Blood remains after the sick person has received Communion, it should be consumed by the minister, who should also see to it that the vessel is properly purified."

Comment: The forests in northern Alberta routinely burn down about twice per century. The forests in the Fort McMurray area last burned down in the 1960s - I remember the fires - and the trees have now regrown to the point where they are big enough to have another major forest fire. It's part of the natural cycle up there. The major difference is that, unlike last time, there was a city of 100,000+ people in the way of the fire. If you have a bush town of few hundred people, they all evacuate the town, they all wait until it is over, and then if they find their log cabin is a smoldering ruin, they cut down some fire-damaged trees and build a new one. If you have a major city with big suburbs, big schools, and big hospitals, it's a major disaster.

Comment: This article highlights two issues plaguing dentistry - 
Mr. Doyle is a practice broker, paid on commission and therefore, it is in his interest to keep prices of practices high.  If demand for dental services is decreasing, then the Law of Supply and Demand would suggest that the value of practices which deliver these services to the public would also decrease.    
The entry of equity investor-backed dental service organizations (DSO), like Dentalcorp and many others which are not regulated and are not transparent to the public, were the brokers' best friends until they grew large enough to have their own recruiting team.  They control the doctor-patient relationship, as do the insurance companies.  DSO groups are not regulated. 
The rights of dentists and the public are at higher risk when third-parties control the doctor-patient relationship.
As a patient advocate and supporter of independent practice, the solution is education.  Unfortunately, this article missed that opportunity.

Comment: Clearly the market is changing and the news organizations of yesterday won't survive today. Pouring more public money into a broken model won't fix the problem. Ad revenue would then be earned by the private broadcasters, who would be more financially stable. The second recommendation is to address the credibility problem most mainstream media outlets have. Once these recommendations are done, then we can talk about public subsidizes.

As recently as Arizona v. United States, the Supreme Court has stated that the Executive branch has prosecutorial discretion in deciding how to allocate resources when enforcing laws. As explained in a Slate article:
“Congress sets only the outer limits of executive power, like a board of directors giving general marching orders to the CEO of a corporation. The president, like the CEO, makes most of the decisions as to policy as well as to enforcement. Congress can prevent the president from doing certain things by refusing to grant him authorization to do them. But Congress generally cannot force the president to enforce a statute if he does not want to."

Comment: A little background. The first schools for Alaska Natives were started by the Russians in those parts of Alaska they controlled. After they sold the place to Seward the US government wished to extend the law of the land, mandatory education for children, to Alaska but had no infrastructure to do it. Enter Commissioner for Education Sheldon Jackson who talked the major religious denominations of America into establishing schools (and churches) and the state was divied up between them. English was the only language these new educators knew yet many Natives saw the advantage of one language, mathematics, reading and writing and other "western" knowledge so local schools were appreciated and well attended. But all villages were not included because of the cost so eventually boarding schools were created and some of them were really unacceptable by any measure. So some children faired well while others were sent into a poorly supervised system and hence Mr. LaBelle's story, shared by many.

Comment: There are, as usual, many causal or root layers to each Trumpish issue.  In this example (to be simplistic), at the highest level is some question on whether the USA can or must benefit from free-ish trade or at another level, whether the USA has any vested interest in trade when it can pretty well make anything it wants domestically (more or less) and if so, under what set of circumstances.... And the answers to these higher-general-principle issues lead to more detailed or adjacent ones like, if you are going to trade does that have any relationship to your other foreign policy priorities and does that in turn relate to how much you can afford to pay (literally) to "buy American" as an absolute and then when you answer that and find that you probably cannot pay for regressive trade practices AND all the other things you have promised or conceived, how much of the protectionism can you afford and with respect to what and so on.

Dairy and softwood are non-issues in all of this.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: OK, I'm gonna get in trouble for saying this, but my theory would be that it's "local style."  Not all locals, mind you, but what I mean by that is how we are comfortable with the status quo and are often afraid of change, even if it might benefit you.  Do you have a favorite supermarket?  Store F perhaps?  Why?  Is it because your parents always shopped there even if Store T is cheaper?  Do you have a favorite gas station?  Favorite insurance company?  And more recently, favorite cell phone carrier?  Look at the way we fought the plastic bag ban and now the proposed foam container ban.  I'm also old enough to remember when the streets in Waikiki were changed to alternating one way and how people fought it.  Creatures of habit.  Of course this doesn't apply to everyone and eventually, some changes are made, such as the plastic bag ban, but it takes a while to accomplish it and most often, we end up liking the change.  The answer is term limits.

Comment: The Seward Highway south of Potters Marsh is essentially a two-lane country road between major urban areas.  A two lane country road with tandem tractor trailers, motorcycles, RVs, pick-ups towing enormous boats, gawking tourists, and Alaskans just trying to get somewhere. The speed variance between these vehicles is dangerous.  Nowhere else in America will you find anything like it. Compound that danger with falling rocks and hazardous winter conditions.  Aggressive traffic enforcement does little to address the fundamental problem that it is a woefully inadequate road for the traffic it receives. The state should be applauded for recognizing the problem. Indeed, let’s straighten and move the road and build all the quarries necessary to do that.

Comment: Unfortunately,  the writer misses a couple of critical issues.  Most of those other "civilized" countries don't have our extremely adversarial legal system, for starters.  A significant % of your healthcare premium is _lawsuit_  insurance, not medical - every insurance company, hospital chain, and pharmaceutical manufacturer out there has to spend $10s of millions on legal fees every year, chasing off the scumsuckers (even if the defendants rarely lose a suit) .   

That cost has to be passed along to the end users (we the patients), of course.  :-/   I don't see this situation changing just because a government-backed single-payer comes in.  (Indeed, it could get worse.  Lawsuits would  be filed for $100s of millions instead of mere millions - the Government has infinitely-deep pockets, right?)

Then there is the question of other societal priorities.  The USA as the de facto global policeman spends a helluva lot on the military that other countries don't have to.

Comment: Since retiring, we've visited hundreds of Gateway/Visitor centers around the US and Canada. Most do a terrific job of building, maintaining, staffing, and stocking their centers with all the info one needs to plan a stay: what to do, where to go, where to stay, shop, eat, how to experience a region to its fullest, buy a t-shirt, or a coffee. GH is THE major gateway to the Olympic National Park, spectacular beaches, rich recreational opportunities and natural beauty. You have strong partners for this venture: National Park Service (I've seen centers with an NPS booth), US Forest Service (same here; check out their Olympia digs if you haven't already), local Native American tribes (we've seen some spectacular visitor/cultural centers with displays, films, and beautiful merchandise), the cities, county, the hotel/restaurant/small business community, real estate cos., etc. GH needs and deserves a first-rate project like this, with bathrooms, parking, and positive people. Tami Garrow
